sen.j: 鈴木 馬左也（すずき まさや、文久元年2月24日 (旧暦)（1861年4月3日） - 大正11年（1922年）12月25日）は、第三代住友総理事である。
sen.e: Masaya SUZUKI (April 3, 1861 - December 25, 1922) was the third general director of Sumitomo Group.
sen.cmt: 「総理事」の訳：google booksで"shunnosuke furuta sumitomo"で検索（古田俊之助は第7代総理事）→"Corporate Financing and Governance in Japan: The Road to the Future"のp.71に"general director"とあります。
sen.e: Masaya SUZUKI (April 3, 1861 - December 25, 1922) was the third general director of Sumitomo Group.
Masaya SUZUKI (April 3, 1861 - December 25, 1922) was the third general director of Sumitomo Group.

sen.j: 文久元年（1861年）2月24日、高鍋藩家老の父秋月種節（たねよ）と久子の四男として、日向国高鍋（現・宮崎県児湯郡高鍋町）で生まれた。
sen.e: Suzuki was born as the fourth son of Taneyo Akizuki, who was Karo (chief retainer) of Takanabe Domain, and his wife Hisako in Takanabe, Hyuga Province (present-day Takanabe-cho, Koyu County, Miyazaki Prefecture).

sen.e: He was born as the fourth son of Karo (chief retainer) of the Takanabe clan, Taneyo Akizuki and his wife Hisako in Takanabe, Hyuga Province (present Takanabe-cho, Koyu County, Miyazaki Prefecture).
He was born as the fourth son of Karo (chief retainer) of the Takanabe clan, Taneyo Akizuki and his wife Hisako in Takanabe, Hyuga Province (present Takanabe-cho, Koyu County, Miyazaki Prefecture).

sen.j: 明治元年、母方の大叔父鈴木翔房（たかふさ）が七五歳で没し、その養子衞房（もりふさ）も戊申の役に加わり、27歳で戦死した。
sen.e: In 1868, maternal grand-uncle Takafusa SUZUKI died at age 75, and his adopted son Morifusa who joined Boshin War also died in the battlefield at age 27.
In 1868, his maternal grand-uncle Takafusa SUZUKI died at the age of 75, and Takafusa's adopted son Morifusa also died in the battle of the Boshin War at the age of 27.

sen.e: In 1868, his maternal grand-uncle Takafusa SUZUKI died at the age of 75, and Takafusa's adopted son Morifusa also died in the battle of the Boshin War at the age of 27.

sen.j: 翌2年、馬左也は鈴木家再興のため、戦死した衞房の養子となり同家を継いだ。
sen.e: In 1869, Masaya was registered as an adopted child of war-dead Morifusa to rebuild Suzuki family and inherit the family headship.
In 1869, Masaya was registered as an adopted child of the war-dead Morifusa to rebuild the Suzuki family and inherit the family headship.

sen.j: 明治９年旧制宮崎中学を卒業し、同年金沢の啓明学校へ入学した。
sen.e: In 1876, he finished Miyazaki Junior High School under the old system of education and enrolled to Keimei School in Kanazawa.

sen.j: だが翌年退学、11年から東京帝国大学予備門に入学。
sen.e: However, Suzuki withdrew from Keimei school next year and began to learn at Preparatory School of Tokyo Imperial University.

sen.e: However, he withdrew from Keimei School the next year and in 1878 entered the preparatory school of Tokyo Imperial University.

sen.j: 明治20年、27歳で東京大学を卒業すると内務省 (日本)に入り、22年愛媛県書記官として赴任した。
sen.e: In 1887, he graduated from Tokyo University and joined Ministry of Home Affairs at the age of 27, then he was transferred to Ehime Prefecture as a secretary.

sen.j: 翌年別子銅山開坑200年祭に来賓として新居浜に招かれ、住友との最初の出会いをはたす。
sen.e: In 1888, Suzuki was invited to the 200-year anniversary of the opening of Besshi-dozan Copper mine held in Nihama as a guest, which became his first encounter with Sumitomo Group.
The next year he was invited to the 200th anniversary of the opening of the Besshi Copper Mine held in Niihama as a guest, which became his first encounter with the House of Sumitomo.

sen.e: The next year he was invited to the 200th anniversary of the opening of the Besshi Copper Mine held in Niihama as a guest, which became his first encounter with the House of Sumitomo.

sen.j: 明治29年1896年、農商務省 (日本)参事官を退官し、住友に入社、大阪本店の副支配人となる。
sen.e: In 1896, Suzuki resigned as a counselor of Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce to join Sumitomo Group as an assistant manager of Osaka headquarters.
In 1896, he resigned as counselor of the Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce (Japan) to enter a company of the House of Sumitomo, and became assistant manager of the head office of Osaka.

sen.e: In 1896, he resigned as counselor of the Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce (Japan) to enter a company of the House of Sumitomo, and became assistant manager of the head office of Osaka.

sen.j: 明治32年（1899年）別子鉱業所支配人となる。
sen.e: In 1899, he became manager of Besshi Kogyo-sho (Besshi mining industry).
In 1899, he became manager of Besshi Kogyo-sho (Sumitomo Copper Plant of Besshi).

sen.e: In 1899, he became manager of Besshi Kogyo-sho (Sumitomo Copper Plant of Besshi).

sen.j: 伊庭貞剛の別子大造林計画を継承し大正6年（1917年）から北海道北見から、九州宮崎県の椎葉村まで山林事業を起こし、また朝鮮の国有林にまで植林を敢行した。
sen.e: Inheriting Besshi great afforestation plan originally launched by Teigo IBA, Suzuki started forestation business in 1917 from Kitami in Hokkaido down to Shiba Village in Miyazaki Prefecture in Kyushu, and further extended afforestation to national forest in Korea.

He took over the project of planting a forest of Besshi originally launched by Teigo IBA, and in 1917 started afforestation business from Kitami in Hokkaido down to Shiiba Village of Miyazaki Prefecture in Kyushu, and further extended afforestation business to the national forest in Korea.
sen.cmt: 「椎葉」はShiiba。わかりやすくします。

sen.j: 大正2年新居浜の煙害問題解決のひとつとして住友肥料製造所（現、住友化学）を開設した。
sen.e: In 1913, Suzuki founded Sumitomo Hiryo Seizo-sho (Sumitomo fertilizer manufacturing, current Sumitomo Chemical) as a part of effort to solve Nihama's air pollution problem by smoke.
In 1913, Suzuki founded Sumitomo Hiryo Seizo-sho (Sumitomo Fertilizer Factory, current Sumitomo Chemical) as a measure to control Niihama's smoke pollution.

sen.j: 明治37年（1904年）第三代総理事に就任。
sen.e: Before that year, Suzuki was already appointed as the third general director in 1904.

sen.j: 明治44年住友電線製造所（現、住友電工）を設立。
sen.e: In 1911, he founded Sumitomo Densen Seizo-sho (Sumitomo electric wire manufacturing, current Sumitomo Electric Industries).
In 1911, he founded Sumitomo Densen Seizo-sho (Sumitomo Electric Wire and Cable Works, current Sumitomo Electric Industries).

sen.j: 明治45年には伸銅場（現、住友金属・住友軽金属）で継ぎ目なし鋼管の製造に着手し、海軍の復水管需要に応える。
sen.e: In 1912, he started the production of seamless steel pipes in Sumitomo Shindo-jo (Sumitomo copper processing, current Sumitomo Metals and Sumitomo Light Metal Industries) to meet with demand of condensate pipes from navy.

In 1912, he started the production of seamless steel pipes in Sumitomo Shindo-jo (Sumitomo Copper Plant, current Sumitomo Metals and Sumitomo Light Metal Industries) to meet the demand of the navy's condensation pipes.

sen.e: In 1912, he started the production of seamless steel pipes in Sumitomo Shindo-jo (Sumitomo Copper Plant, current Sumitomo Metals and Sumitomo Light Metal Industries) to meet the demand of the navy's condensation pipes.

sen.j: 大正2年（1913年）住友肥料製造所（現住友化学）を設立し、同8年大阪の臨海工業地帯建設のために大阪北港（後の、住友土地工務）を設立した。
sen.e: In 1913, Suzuki founded Sumitomo Hiryo Seizo-sho (Sumitomo fertilizer manufacturing, current Sumitomo Chemical), followed by the foundation of Osaka Kita-ko (Osaka north port, subsequent Sumitomo Land and Construction) in 1919.

In 1913 he founded Sumitomo Hiryo Seizo-sho (current Sumitomo Chemical), and in 1919 built Osaka Hokko (the North Port of Osaka, the predecessor of Sumitomo Land and Construction) for the coastal industrial areas of Osaka.

sen.e: In 1913 he founded Sumitomo Hiryo Seizo-sho (current Sumitomo Chemical), and in 1919 built Osaka Hokko (the North Port of Osaka, the predecessor of Sumitomo Land and Construction) for the coastal industrial areas of Osaka.

sen.j: さらに同年、別子鉱山の電源開発を目的に土佐吉野川水力電気（後の住友共同電力）、宮崎県の椎葉植林に関係して耳川の水利権を確保した。
sen.e: In that year, Suzuki further founded Tosa Yoshino-gawa Suiryoku Denki (Tosa Yoshino-gawa river hydroelectric, subsequent Sumitomo Joint Electric Power), as well as the acquisition of water right of Mimikawa river in connection with the afforestation in Shiba, Miyazaki Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 土佐吉野川水力電気（設立？）（四国）と耳川水利権確保（九州）は別々の案件か不明です。
sen.e: In that year, he also founded Tosa Yoshino-gawa Suiryoku Denki (Tosa Yoshino-gawa River Hydroelectric Power Plant, the predecessor of Sumitomo Joint Electric Power) for the development of the power supply in Besshi copper mine, and acquired the water right of Mimi-kawa River for the afforestation project in Shiiba, Miyazaki Prefecture.

As in 1921 he reorganized the head office of Sumitomo into a joint-stock company, he significantly contributed to the development of the Sumitomo Group.
